body: zipkin 2.26.0 includes ES 8.x support
zipkin 2.26.0 includes ES 8.x support

This hasn't moved in half a year, so I added you and @jonkerj as maintainers of https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-helm, so that you can make adjustments directly. If you need to publish to zipkin.io, you can also from there. For example, we do this both here and in brave (hint look at build-bin/deploy in either)

this hasn't moved in half a year, so I added you to https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-helm so you can work with the others and make changes as needed directly. Later, we should remove the helm assets from here.

TL;DR; I know this is a compromised position, but I've been told that experiments have been taking place and also that things don't work and have been blocked also. Moving this to a separate repo and deleting from here when done is the most sensible way out. I've added several recent contributors as maintainers to https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-helm

---

I made an executive decision to move the contents here to a new repo for reasons described above and that a couple contributors were blocked for half a year https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-helm I added those blocked as maintainers and also @optional303 in case there's consolidation interest from https://github.com/Financial-Times/zipkin-helm

This helps make the following true:
* helm experience is coordinated in one place and people can watch for changes only about helm in one place
* zipkin's repo gets coherent versions and tags again
* zipkin-helm can introduce features for [zipkin-dependencies](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-dependencies), which is hosted in a different repository and produces different versions of docker images.
  * same is the case with [zipkin-gcp](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-gcp) and [zipkin-aws](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-aws)

As noted on some other issues, the final url for helm may want to be under zipkin.io. being under a different repo is fine, as right now, both zipkin and brave publish javadoc under zipkin.io.

a combination of factors including abandoned and/or unmerged PRs, as well version and tag clutter in this repo led to moving helm to its own repo, owned by its contributors. Looking forward to https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-helm/issues/1 completing and things getting online again.

@mrfelek FYI, a combination of factors including abandoned and/or unmerged PRs, as well version and tag clutter in this repo led to moving helm to its own repo, owned by its contributors including you. Looking forward to help with https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-helm/issues/1 so that things are online and folks can move easily.

I'm closing this out because over the last three weeks I can say for sure the number one issue in zipkin is not a technical one. There's no single image or library to blame on what was unintentional neglect by committers. I found pull requests not progressed in three years, and the attempt to move to ES 8 was almost complete, just didn't hook up the test image. Armeria wasn't the issue, it was lack of sustained attention from maintainers, from what is likely a lack of stake in things that are difficult or annoying to complete.

TL;DR; There's no reason to chase down and undo the work we did to get small docker images and performant elasticsearch. If there is technical budget for time, spend it more wisely probably on cassandra 5 storage attached indices or similar. What would be better than that would be connecting to sites and seeing who can help move zipkin forward in a sustainable way, doing as we have done in keeping things minimal, coherent, current and tested.

I will create the scaffolding this morning like zipkin-gcp for https://github.com/openzipkin-contrib/zipkin-otel this would also allow the [handler](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-reporter-java/pull/213) or some variant there as well. Folks can also choose whether or not to, for convenience, migrate in the [propagation module for tracestate](https://github.com/openzipkin-contrib/brave-propagation-w3c). One reason to do that could be easy versioning.

in general please follow pattern of zipkin-gcp in decisions for how to config, where to add modules, etc. It will make it easy for people to swap into zipkin-otel and also remove some bikeshedding from naming conventions

cc @marcingrzejszczak @shakuzen

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3671 will close out this, as there are still requests about it. If folks want more discovery options, we can try to support, but raise new issues corresponding to them

fyi eureka will end up as an option for registration of zipkin, but not discovery of resources zipkin uses. other options for registration are discussable, but there is work involved to do it right.

See https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3671
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3671 will add eureka registration
Almost there.. green, but zipkin-server is redundantly testing the other docker stuff due to --am. I think we should do a build pass first, *then* run tests, and not use --am. I'll do it
Thanks for the review and suggestions @anuraaga and thanks for the review on the prior PR @minwoox. more work can happen post merge as necessary.
p.s. for folks at home, remember zipkin publishes a new docker image on commits to master, so you can try this via `ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin:master` (not latest which is last released)

the problems here were mostly test lifecycle in nature (properties read at the wrong time), so https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3671 walked around them by using testcontainers+dynamic properties instead of nested initialization. https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-server/src/test/java/zipkin2/server/internal/eureka/ITZipkinEureka.java

are you able to try the master docker tag, which adjusts the wget timeout?

There are a couple articles which hint this could be about the HEALTHCHECK process quitting before wget does. If you are using in-memory storage it could be slow GC that could cause this? What is the output of /health? that will show what is running..

https://github.com/gliderlabs/docker-consul/issues/45
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77105400/docker-compose-hundreds-of-health-check-processes-not-terminated
https://github.com/zadam/trilium/issues/3582

@anuraaga I wonder if we shouldn't change our HEALTHCHECK interval to 2s, as in worst case even a timed out wget or nc would result in slightly more than a second. We keep a tight interval to help responsiveness in dev, but 2s is also not a big deal vs 1s.. wdyt?

I think changing the interval would be fine if it solves the problem. From what it sounds like, it would at best solve it or at worst make it extremely unlikely (maybe there's some reason other than timeout that causes health check script to get killed before wget).

I found this thread about patterns to propagate kill to child processes. It looks wordy but maybe it's worth doing instead or in addition to tweaking the interval?

https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/146756/forward-sigterm-to-child-in-bash

Another idea but not recommendation is replacing the shell script+wget with a small cross compiled go binary.

@anuraaga interesting idea on a cross-compiled healthcheck binary... I guess it would be most appropriate to compile and add to https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-alpine, since there's nothing java about it. Are you interested enough to emulate the shell script in Go or favorite and add it there?

> https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/146756/forward-sigterm-to-child-in-bash

seems like it wants us to background the child so we can handle signals manually. I worry about this being hard to test and may become worse if not carefully done..

Agree it is tricky, I was hoping to just find some setopt to propagate signals 

I can look at adding a health binary to docker-alpine, it may take a few days to get to it

> I can look at adding a health binary to docker-alpine, it may take a few days to get to it

used openrewrite to migrate tests and server code to 17, by doing this and reverting the opposite

https://docs.openrewrite.org/recipes/java/migrate/upgradetojava17
```
mvn -U org.openrewrite.maven:rewrite-maven-plugin:run -Drewrite.recipeArtifactCoordinates=org.openrewrite.recipe:rewrite-migrate-java:RELEASE -Drewrite.activeRecipes=org.openrewrite.java.migrate.UpgradeToJava17
```

@timtebeek fyi, the last commit fixes some things that were mostly, but not completely done with the 17 update recipe. It seemed to dislike some things about how our linefeeds work as well unicode specifically
@timtebeek just a hunch, but I think it is about multi-line literal conversion where the <17 has no trailing newline or unicode. Was easy to fix these, so no biggie!

so the health endpoint is mentioned here, but yeah not well documented. We also use this for the HEALTHCHECK directive in docker. I'll move this issue to the main repo, noting that there is an emerging https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-helm which should master the info on k8s stuff

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-server#endpoints
besides normal motivation, one is to make sure things pass before adding new links for #3649
I refactored this to be coherent with the other steps we do like `test` and `deploy`. This makes it easy to verify on your laptop the same as CI would do.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3692 for the readme
https://github.com/openzipkin/openzipkin.github.io/pull/178 for the website

So, in summary, probably we should coalesce on a practice before documenting one, but gut feel is adapting from our Dockerfile one is not a bad start. We probably need some advice to clarify lack of startup and liveness probes in the ecosystem, e.g. if that's a feature or a bug. cc @mfordjody @optional303

---

To begin this, /health is a composite status of the heath of zipkin's dependencies. For example, if zipkin is configured for stackdriver or kafka and either connection don't work, /health will return non 200 code.

here is the text on out HEALTHCHECK in docker, which ack is [disabled for k8s](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/50703), but is the same basic info

```
# We use start period of 30s to avoid marking the container unhealthy on slow or contended CI hosts.
#
# If in production, you have a 30s startup, please report to https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
# including the values of the /health and /info endpoints as this would be unexpected.
HEALTHCHECK --interval=5s --start-period=30s --timeout=5s CMD ["docker-healthcheck"]
```
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/docker/Dockerfile#L66-L70

From https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-liveness-readiness-startup-probes/
> A common pattern for liveness probes is to use the same low-cost HTTP endpoint as for readiness probes, but with a higher failureThreshold.

The incubating zipkin-helm chart in this org seems to have defined readiness, but not liveness, from docker HEALTHCHECK, notably missing the start period

```yaml
          readinessProbe:
            httpGet:
              path: /health
              port: 9411
            initialDelaySeconds: 5
            periodSeconds: 5
```
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-helm/blob/475ebd84f98992d423ef5d417756c388c9cdfb68/charts/zipkin/templates/deployment.yaml#L71-L76

The setup above is consistent with a few other helm charts including https://github.com/radius-project/radius/blob/21b25ddf265f0464e4641b8c79cff61a4f9badd0/deploy/monitoring/zipkin-mem.yaml#L19 and https://github.com/apache/dubbo-kubernetes/blob/c4f2898e4eacd978c780bec79989a465f3e5a9dd/deploy/kubernetes/zipkin.yaml#L91-L96

That said, Financial Times is using a socket for one and /health for the other, here, defaulting the startup delay to 200
```yaml
          livenessProbe:
            initialDelaySeconds: {{ .Values.ui.probeStartupDelay }}
            tcpSocket:
              port: {{ .Values.ui.queryPort }}
          readinessProbe:
            initialDelaySeconds: {{ .Values.ui.probeStartupDelay }}
            httpGet:
              path: /health
              port: {{ .Values.ui.queryPort }}
```
https://github.com/Financial-Times/zipkin-helm/blob/0ae00a2e2be986b58de30475601ea5dc686ea0fd/templates/zipkin-ui.yaml#L29-L37

@ankit-gautam23 @snower so what I understand here is that the type of tags is incorrect, for example, the value isn't a string, rather something else. So, I am guessing that you are talking about something like.. strange_tag here

```json
{
  "traceId": "4d1e00c0db9010db86154a4ba6e91385",
  "parentId": "86154a4ba6e91385",
  "id": "4d1e00c0db9010db",
  "kind": "CLIENT",
  "name": "get",
  "timestamp": 1472470996199000,
  "duration": 207000,
  "tags": {
    "http.path": "/api",
    "strange_tag": {"nested": "true"}
  }
}

```

So, I think if we did this what would end up happening is that because the indexing is custom, (`"tags": {"enabled": false }` in our index template, search might not be broken. However, since it is permitting broken values when our normal API doesn't allow it, other things might break. For example, our normal json codec should break on an invalid value.

If we do this for Elasticsearch, this does not mean we will do it for our default parser, because it is definitely not conformant data, and people should know that their data is invalid for zipkin. So, I want to set this expectation before we proceed.

If we do have this, not only does it need to be unit tested, but also added as an integration test to make sure it actually works. So, in `ITElasticsearchStorage` add a tests like..

* ITTraces.getTrace_skipsInvalidTagValue
  * lookup of trace by ID that includes a non-string value doesn't break returning it.
* ITSpanStore.getTraces_skipsInvalidTagValue
  * the search key in the query has one trace that matches the correct value and other has a non-string value doesn't break it.
* ITDependencies.getDependencies_linksSkipsInvalidTagValue
  * a trace that is linked based on span kind has a non-string value, and it doesn't break linking
  * This may also break zipkin-dependencies the separate project
* ITAutocompleteTags.skipsInvalidTagValue
  * autocomplete key is set to a trace which has a non-string value, and is ignored.

If any of the above don't work, we shouldn't land this, as it is already very difficult to support ES with template defined for our correct data format. Even if we do land this, it won't be a precedent for changing our core parser which correctly breaks if a tag has a non-string value.

This means we need in the PR a zipkin-storage/elasticsearch/RATIONALE.md for why we are doing this, knowing the index is for zipkin data and this is invalid. This rational should be strong but will not change our default parser, as permitting schema change in something we define as stable is a step backwards not forwards.

ps I will help with the test backfill on current code, as I think it will lead to resolving this one way or another more easy. In some ways this isn't a backfill, because for example, the collector enforces a JSON compliance. I'm pretty certain the only way data like this can end up in zipkin's indexes is if something that isn't zipkin is putting it there. Tests I'll look for and/or backfill will prove this out cc @reta I'll ping you when done maybe a couple days as busy week for me.

my suspicions were correct. Zipkin correctly rejects malformed spans, so if any are in zipkin's indices, something else wrote them. We only support our schema for use in our collectors, so beyond this is unsupported. It would need to be a compelling reason to attempt to support malformed data considering how few people help with Elasticsearch and how many problems we routinely have even with the supported config https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3695

I assume it is ok to use a different USERNAME and PASSWORD property instead of coding inside the URL, right?

seems this is because when you make your own eureka server with spring, it defaults to literally user=username password=password https://cloud.spring.io/spring-cloud-netflix/multi/multi__service_discovery_eureka_clients.html#_authenticating_with_the_eureka_server

I think to get this across the finish line, it might be faster to redo it. Reason is that the cassandra property is `SSL_HOSTNAME_VALIDATION` and so that means our property should be `CASSANDRA_SSL_HOSTNAME_VALIDATION` for env and sslHostnameValidation for the field. using different names can cause confusion. Most of the work not done here is adding the spring yaml plumbing to propagate this setting, as well update the zipkin-server README section for cassandra.
